children: Dysplastic nevi have some features of melanoma, including:
a “fried egg” appearance with a darker, elevated central portion and tan, flat shoulders blending into the surrounding skin
pigmentation ranging from light tan to dark brown and occasionally black
Dysplastic nevi are markers for an increased risk of melanoma.

Autosomal-dominant familial melanoma/dysplastic nevus syndrome is defined by the presence of melanoma in at least two relatives; more than 50 nevi, with multiple nevi having atypical clinical and histologic features; and dysplastic nevi in other family members.

Dysplastic nevi that develop increased characteristics associated with melanoma (fuzzy or ill-defined borders, multiple colors, diameter ≥5 mm), have otherwise changed, or stand out from other nevi must be removed and sent for pathology.
